heading.title: DIVISION 4 APPEALS FROM THE LOCAL COURT [ss 38–41]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 4 APPEALS FROM THE LOCAL COURT [ss 38–41]
[LCA07 s 38] s 38 Judgments and orders final (cf LCA 1982, section 72)

leg:heading.title: Judgments and orders final (cf LCA 1982, section 72 )

p.text: Subject to this Division, all judgments and orders of the Court exercising jurisdiction under this Part are final and conclusive.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 38.5] Discovery of fresh evidence after judgment

heading.title: Discovery of fresh evidence after judgment

p.text: The Local Court's judgment is final. For an appellate court to direct a new trial on the basis that fresh evidence has been discovered, three conditions must be fulfilled: “First, it must be shown that the evidence could not have been obtained with reasonable diligence for use at the trial; secondly, the evidence must be such that, if given, it would probably have an important influence on the result of the case, though it need not be decisive; thirdly, the evidence must be such as is presumably to be believed, or in other words, it must be apparently credible, though it need not be incontrovertible”: Ladd v Marshall [1954] 3 All ER 745; [1954] 1 WLR 1489 at 1491 per Denning LJ, applied in Orchard v Orchard (1972) 3 SASR 89 and Ventura v Sustek (1976) 14 SASR 395 ; see also Falasca v Morrissy (ACTSC, Gallop, Higgins and Crispin JJ, No 73/97, 6 May 1998, unreported, BC9801587). For elucidation of the second condition see Orr v Holmes (1948) 76 CLR 632; 22 ALJR 283; BC4800240 ; Greater Wollongong City Council v Cowan (1955) 93 CLR 435; 29 ALJR 36; BC5500160 (especially per Dixon CJ at 444); Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Quade (1991) 178 CLR 134 at 140; 102 ALR 487; [1993] HCA 55; BC9102605 .

The test for the second condition applied by the High Court in McDonald v McDonald (1965) 113 CLR 529 at 534; [1966] ALR 496 at 498; BC6500430 per Barwick CJ was even higher than that stated by Denning LJ, being that “the evidence, if believed, would probably be conclusive of the issue between the parties”. In the same case, Windeyer J said that “except in very exceptional cases perjury is not a sufficient ground for setting aside a judgment”: CLR at 544; ALR at 505. This is the test which was applied by the New South Wales Court of Appeal in Kervan Trading Pty Ltd v Mercantile Mutual Insurance (Aust) Ltd [2000] NSWCA 356; BC200007779 (the plaintiff's claim was rejected at first instance because the defendant's defence of fraud had been made out; the plaintiff adduced fresh evidence to the effect that a mother and daughter had given perjured evidence to harm him; the Court of Appeal declined to order a new trial (Mason P dissenting), on the basis that the appellant must prove that the evidence if believed would probably be conclusive of the issue between the parties; the most that could be said of the fresh evidence in this case was that the trial judge would have to rethink some of his conclusions). In seeking to have a judgment set aside because of fraud, the plaintiff must bring forward evidence of fresh facts to prove the fraud, but that is all. There is no need to prove due diligence in the discovery of the fraud as well: Jonesco v Beard [1930] AC 298 at 301–2; [1930] All ER Rep 483 at 485 per Lord Buckmaster, applied in Toubia v Schwenke (2002) 54 NSWLR 46; 36 MVR 159; [2002] NSWCA 34; BC200200540 . In Vogt v Mercer [2001] NSWCA 3; BC200100421 , the New South Wales Court of Appeal considered the matter on the basis of the test enunciated in Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Quade (1991) 178 CLR 134; 102 ALR 487; [1993] HCA 55; BC9102605 , that “it is not necessary that the appellate court be persuaded that it is ‘almost certain’ or ‘reasonably clear’ that an opposite result would have been produced. The question whether the verdict should be set aside would almost inevitably be answered in the negative if it does not appear that there is at least a real possibility that that would have been so”. In Vogt (fresh video evidence of plaintiff produced), above, this was the test applied by the Court of Appeal on the basis that it was most favourable to the appellant who was seeking a new trial. The application still failed.

“If an application is made to re-open on the basis that new or additional evidence is available, it will be relevant, at that stage, to inquire why the evidence was not called at the hearing … different considerations may well apply depending on whether the case is simply one in which the hearing is complete, or one in which reasons for judgment have been delivered. It is difficult to see why, in the former situation, the primary consideration should not be that of embarrassment or prejudice to the other side”: Smith v New South Wales Bar Assn (1992) 176 CLR 256 at 266-7; 108 ALR 55 at 61–2; BC9202693 .

It is submitted that the Local Court has no jurisdiction to entertain a motion to set aside a judgment on the basis that fresh evidence has come to light, because it is a creature of statute and its judgment, once regularly entered, is final. It would appear that the only way of bringing the matter before the Supreme Court in the event of the discovery of fresh evidence satisfying the above criteria would be by way of proceedings removing the matter into the Supreme Court seeking a new trial ex debito justitiae. However, the Local Court does have the discretion to entertain a motion to reopen the proceedings after the evidence and submissions have concluded. For an instance in the Supreme Court where the plaintiff was given leave to reopen the proceedings to adduce further evidence in these circumstances, see Marshall v Wallerawang Collieries Pty Ltd [1999] NSWSC 937; BC9905847 . The court took into account the fact that the evidence was not available to the plaintiff before the hearing concluded. Nevertheless, having regard to the factors hitherto adverted to in this paragraph, such applications are sparingly granted: compare Citibank Ltd v Papandony [2002] NSWSC 678; BC200204343 , a Supreme Court case involving a defendant's application to reopen its case after publication of reasons but before entry of judgment not capable of being entertained in the Local Court but relevant by analogy. “I do not regard the interests of the applicant in seeking to re-open this matter as outweighing the public interest in finality of litigation. In my view the interests of justice are best served by refusing to re-open the matter”: at [29] per Gzell J.

In the absence of a judgment or order, the appeal procedures in the Act (formerly by way of stated case) cannot be invoked: Hunyh v Swanson [1999] NSWSC 490; BC9900622 , applying Johnson v Gibbings (1895) 11 WN (NSW) 137 ; Ex parte Hornsby Shire Council; Re Crandon (1935) 53 WN (NSW) 22 ; Hope v Bathurst City Council [1980] 1 NSWLR 535 ; Huntof v Quach (NSWCA, 7 May 2001, unreported). In Hunyh v Swanson, above, the magistrate simply held that he had no jurisdiction. Since this was not a judgment or order, the plaintiff sought a declaration in the Supreme Court that he did in fact have jurisdiction, and further orders in the nature of certiorari and mandamus.

heading.title: Finality of judgments or orders — the slip rule

p.text: Where there has been “a clerical mistake, or an error arising from an accidental slip or omission, in a judgment or order, or in a certificate, the court, on the application of any party or of its own motion, may, at any time, correct the mistake or error”: UCPR r 36.17 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 39] s 39 Appeals as of right (cf LCA 1982, section 73)

leg:heading.title: Appeals as of right (cf LCA 1982, section 73 )

p.text: A party to proceedings before the Court sitting in its General Division who is dissatisfied with a judgment or order of the Court may appeal to the Supreme Court, but only on a question of law.

A party to proceedings before the Court sitting in its Small Claims Division who is dissatisfied with a judgment or order of the Court may appeal to the District Court, but only on the ground of lack of jurisdiction or denial of procedural fairness.
[subs (2) am Act 53 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 15[2], effective 1 September 2008]
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 39.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 Sections 39, 40, s 75A.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 ss 39, 40.
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 69(3).

Sections 39 and 40 must be read together with s 75A of the Supreme Court Act 1970, as to which see the commentary at [25,005] ff. As to appeals from the General Division to the Supreme Court generally, see [25,005] ff. As to appeals from the Court's Small Claims Division, see [22,010.100] ff. The concept of “denial of natural justice” is considered at [22,010.105] . The drafting of LCA 2007 ss 39 and 40 (formerly LCA 1982 ss 73 and 74 ) removes an ambiguity, noted by Malpass AsJ in Maitland City Council v Murdoch [2005] NSWSC 726; BC200505703 at [30] , as to whether Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 69(3) (repealed) conferred a right of appeal on questions of mixed law and fact from the court's Small Claims Division.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 39.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.10.

An application by the defendant for a verdict pursuant to UCPR r 29.10 on the basis that there was “no evidence” to support a verdict for the plaintiff involves a question of law, and the application is to be determined by a consideration of the plaintiff’s case at its highest: Shamieh t/as Consolidated Lawyers v Easy Buy International Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 970; BC201006357 .

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 39.10] LCA 2007 s 39(2) — Denial of procedural fairness

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 39(2) — Denial of procedural fairness

p.text: LCA 1982 s 73(2) referred to a denial of ‘natural justice’as the basis for appeal in the Small Claims Division. Denying a person the right to call admissible evidence which that person wishes to call to rebut a claim or charge is a denial of natural justice: HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 at [97] per McHugh J; as is denying a party the right to tender admissible evidence in support of his or her claim: Hamod v Suncorp Metway Insurance Ltd [2006] NSWCA 243; BC200606830 , or denying an adjournment where the refusal of the adjournment may be said to bring about a miscarriage of justice: HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 at [100] per McHugh J. For the purposes of the appeal, the appellant will need to demonstrate legal error, not merely an erroneous ruling, and the error must be material to the outcome of the decision appealed from; that is, the decision must be one which is ‘vitiated by error’: Hamod v Suncorp Metway Insurance Ltd, above,at [11]; Leichhardt Municipal Council v Seatainer Terminals Pty Ltd (1981) 48 LGRA 409 at 419 (cited with approval in Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd (in liq) v Darling Harbour Authority (Paddy Markets case) (1991) 24 NSWLR 156 at 177; 73 LGRA 47 per Handley J). However, error of law simpliciter is not a ground for appeal in the Small Claims Division: Habra v Reinke [2005] NSWSC 1090; BC200508854 , per Malpass AsJ, noted at [22,010.105] . The error must equate with a denial of procedural fairness.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 39.15] LCA 2007 s 39(2) — Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court

heading.title: LCA 2007 s 39(2) — Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court

p.text: Only the District Court and not the Supreme Court has jurisdiction to hear an appeal from a Local Court judgment sitting in its Small Claims Division on the grounds of lack of jurisdiction or denial of procedural fairness. It is a statutory appeal: Singh v Owners — Strata Plan 11723 [2012] NSWSC 519; BC201203357 at [31] (application to transfer District Court proceedings involving appeal from Local Court Small Claims judgment to the Supreme Court dismissed.

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 39.20] Jurisdictional error, error of law on the face of the record

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 39.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 69, s 69(3), s 69(4).

heading.title: Jurisdictional error, error of law on the face of the record

p.text: Where these issues arise, s 69 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 gives the Supreme Court jurisdiction to grant any relief or remedy in the nature of a writ of certiorari, which includes jurisdiction to quash the ultimate determination of a court or tribunal in any proceedings if that determination has been made on the basis of an error of law that appears on the face of the record of the proceedings: s 69(3) . The face of the record includes the reasons expressed by the court or tribunal for its ultimate determination ( s 69(4) ). This is not an appellate procedure enabling either a general review of the order or decision, or substitution of the order or decision which the Supreme Court thinks should have been made. “Relief enables the quashing of the impugned order or decision upon one or more of a number of distinct established grounds — jurisdictional error, denial of procedural fairness, fraud and error of law on the face of the record: Craig v South Australia (1994–1995) 184 CLR 163 at 175–176; (1995) 131 ALR 595; 69 ALJR 873; BC9506437 ”: Martin v Kelly [2008] NSWSC 577; BC200804371 at [17] per Johnson J; See also Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission; Kirk Group Holdings Pty Ltd v WorkCover Authority of New South Wales (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 where the High Court discussed the concept of error of law on the face of the record at [78]–[89]. For a more fulsome discussion concerning jurisdictional error, error of law on the face of the record and relief in the Supreme Court, see LexisNexis’ Motor and Traffic Law, Vol 1 at [61,030.35]. See alo Mohamed v Mohamed [2012] NSWSC 852; BC201205576 (contractual debt involving the parties to an Islamic marriage; submission that Magistrate did not have jurisdiction to make a decision concerning Sharia law; held that Sharia law did not arise).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 40] s 40 Appeals requiring leave (cf LCA 1982, section 74)

p.text: A party to proceedings before the Court sitting in its General Division who is dissatisfied with a judgment or order of the Court on a ground that involves a question of mixed law and fact may appeal to the Supreme Court but only by leave of the Supreme Court.

A party to proceedings before the Court sitting in its General Division who is dissatisfied with any of the following judgments or orders of the Court may appeal to the Supreme Court, but only by leave of the Supreme Court:
an interlocutory judgment or order,
a judgment or order made with the consent of the parties,
an order as to costs.
Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 40.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 ss 39, 40(2).
As explained by Deane and Gaudron JJ in Coulter v R (1988) 164 CLR 350 at 359; 76 ALR 365 at 370; BC8802587 per Deane and Gaudron JJ:

The requirement that leave or special leave be obtained before an appeal will lie is a necessary control device in certain areas of the administration of justice (eg, appeals to a second appellate court) in this country. As a filter of the work which comes before some appellate courts, it promotes the availability, the speed and the efficiency of justice in those appeals which are, in all the circumstances, appropriate to proceed to a full hearing before the particular court. It also represents a constraint upon the overall cost of litigation by protecting parties, particularly respondents, from the costs of a full hearing of appeals which should not properly be entertained by the relevant court either because they are hopeless or, in the case of a civil appeal to a second appellate court, because they do not possess special features which outweigh the prima facie validity of the ordinary perception that the availability of cumulative appellate processes can, of itself, constitute a source of injustice.

See also Chapmans Ltd v Yandell [1999] NSWCA 361; BC9906483 per Fitzgerald JA, Mason P and Davies AJA agreeing. These authorities were applied by Davies J in considering an application for leave to appeal against a costs order in Ashi Pty Ltd v Karasco Investments Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 780; BC200907314 (party seeking leave to appeal need s to point to some other matter than ‘a detriment’ which in justice requires that leave to appeal be granted — small quantum of costs order weighed in the balance — leave only granted to include an order that all parties in the court below appear to have believed had already been made). See also Pratten v Johns [2010] NSWSC 327; BC201002418 (mixed question of law and fact requiring leave; leave to appeal refused). In Bagumya v Kakwano [2010] NSWSC 600; BC201003941 , Rothman J raised the possibility that there may be some tension lying between ss 39 and 40(2) , in the event of an error of law arising in an interlocutory judgment. However, in Ciszek v Enterprise Financial Solutions Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1265; BC201008192 , Schmidt J held that, “Notwithstanding the seeming breadth of s 39 … the scheme of the Act is to require leave in a case where a party seeks to appeal an error of law arising in an interlocutory judgment or order. Section 39 must be read as being subject to the particular provisions made in s 40(2) , in the case of interlocutory judgments… Each section must be given the work which it is seemingly intended to do. That will not be achieved if the view is taken that leave to appeal is not required, if an error of law arises in an interlocutory judgment or order” at [10].

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 40.7] Appeals requiring leave under s 39 and 40 of the Local Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 40.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 ss 39, 40, s 40(1), s 40(2), s 49(1).

heading.title: Appeals requiring leave under s 39 and 40 of the Local Court

p.text: “This concern as to protecting parties from the costs of appeals is also evident from three matters in ss 39 and 40 of the Local Court Act. First, it is evident from the restriction imposed by s 39 confining appeals only to questions of law. Secondly, it is evident on the restriction on the extension of such appeals to mixed questions of law and fact that follows from the need to obtain leave under s 49(1) (sic — semble s 40(1) ). Thirdly, it is reflected by the restrictions on leave imposed by s 40(2) . The Local Court has a limited monetary jurisdiction. Left unchecked, appeals from its decisions, especially interlocutory decisions, could lead to there being a significant risk that the overall costs of proceedings would be completely disproportionate to the matters in dispute”: Sayed v Deng [2012] NSWSC 851; BC201205575 at [31]–[33], Beech-Jones J (leave to appeal refused from Magistrate’s decision declining to find that the presentation of a chuqe constituted accord and satisfaction).

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 40.10] LCA 2007 s 40(2) “interlocutory judgment or order”

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 40.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 40(2)(a).

Where a magistrate gives a preliminary decision as to jurisdiction, this constitutes a decision of an interlocutory kind within the meaning of LCA 2007 s 40(2)(a) (formerly LCA 1982 s 74(2)(a) ), and therefore leave to appeal is necessary: Laycock v Putty Community Assn Inc [2006] NSWSC 900; BC200607189 at [22] per Hoeben J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 41] s 41 Determination of appeals (cf LCA 1982, section 75)

p.text: The Supreme Court may determine an appeal made under section 39(1) or 40 :
by varying the terms of the judgment or order, or
by setting aside the judgment or order, or
by setting aside the judgment or order and remitting the matter to the Local Court for determination in accordance with the Supreme Court’s directions, or
by dismissing the appeal.
[subs (1) am Act 53 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 15[3], effective 1 September 2008]
The District Court may determine an appeal made under section 39(2) :
by varying the terms of the judgment or order, or
by setting aside the judgment or order, or
by setting aside the judgment or order and remitting the matter to the Local Court for determination in accordance with the District Court’s directions, or
by dismissing the appeal.
[subs (2) insrt Act 53 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 15[3], effective 1 September 2008]

level.toc-caption: [LCA07 s 41.5] Should the Supreme Court determine the matter?

p.text: Legislation cited in [LCA07 s 41.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 50.16.

heading.title: Should the Supreme Court determine the matter?

p.text: The issue in Thaina Town (On Goulburn) Pty Ltd v City of Sydney Council (2007) 71 NSWLR 230; 156 LGERA 150; [2007] NSWCA 300; BC200709105 was whether the power given to the Supreme Court to “make such other order in relation to the appeal as seems fit”, the words of s 57(2)(b) of the Land and Environment Court Act 1979 (NSW) included a power to award costs pursuant to s 69(2) of that Act. Spigelman CJ, in a judgment with which Mason P and Beazley and Ipp JJA agreed, held (at page 252 (para [103])) that it did and that the power should be exercised “(w)here no new findings of primary facts are to be made … so as to facilitate the just, quick and cheap resolution of the issues in dispute in civil proceedings”. However, in Pacific Asia Express Pty Ltd v Renegade Gas Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1188; BC201007813 , Rein J was not comfortable in doing so under s 41 of the Local Court Act in the particular circumstances of that case. Instead his Honour did so under the power in s 75A of the Supreme Court Act 1970 (NSW). See also, UCPR r 50.16 ; Lee v Surry Hills Mutual Loan Club [2007] NSWSC 650; BC200705046 ; Kells v Waters [2007] NSWSC 885; BC200706422 ; and BDS Recruit Pty Ltd v Parris & Shah Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 614; BC200804757 ; Pool Data Systems Pty Ltd v Bayliss [2011] NSWSC 224; BC201101904 per Hall J (Supreme Court able to determine the quantum of fees to which plaintiff entitled; not necessary to make primary findings of fact; matter capable of being determined on the basis of the evidence in the Local Court). For an instance where the factors in favour of the Supreme Court determining the matter were found to be overwhelming, see Owners Strata Plan 4003 v Mustafa [2012] NSWSC 780; BC201205524 (Beech-Jones J) — principal error made by magistrate basic and fundamental; amount in dispute small; parties should not have to be put to the burden of having to incur a third set of costs to resolve a set of issues which they had narrowed.
